title: Three of the four biggest High Street banks slash their cash Isa rates
text:
Savers are set to suffer further as three of the four biggest High Street banks slash their cash Isa rates.

Experts say it is the worst cash Isa season in three years, with rates tumbling to 0.15 per cent.

Barclays Bank cut its cash Isa rate this morning, while HSBC has announced its rates are set to fall just before Christmas.

Isa slump: Experts say it is the worst cash Isa season in three years, with rates tumbling to 0.15 per cent

They follow hot on the heels of Lloyds Bank, which reduced rates for loyal savers last month. And experts have warned that more cuts could well follow.

From today, savers in Barclays Instant Cash Isa will earn just 0.4 per cent on sums up to £30,000 — or a paltry £4 interest on every £1,000 in the account.

It means they are now earning the same as nearly three years ago when the Bank of England base rate stood at a rock-bottom 0.25 per cent against 0.75 per cent today.

Those with between £30,000 and £100,000 in the Barclays account will earn even less at 0.45 per cent, down from 0.65 per cent.

HSBC’s standard rate on its Loyalty Isa is dropping to 0.5 per cent from December 18.

Last month Lloyds cut its Instant Cash Isa rate from 0.35 per cent to 0.2 per cent.

Other cuts in the pipeline include Tesco Bank; its Instant Access Cash Isa rate will nearly halve from 0.65 per cent to 0.35 per cent from October 24.

TSB now pays only 0.15 per cent on its Cash Isa Saver following cuts last month.

Rachel Springall, finance expert at Moneyfacts, says: ‘Savers will be disappointed with the worst Isa season for three years.’

The average rate on easy-access cash Isas is down at 0.95 per cent compared with 0.98 per cent in April (the time of year when savers qualify for a new annual Isa allowance).

For this tax year you can save up to £20,000 in these tax-free accounts.

NatWest, the only bank out of the big four not to cut its rates so far, already pays a miserly 0.2 per cent on balances up to £10,000 and 0.85 per cent on £50,000 or more.

Other popular accounts such as Halifax Instant Isa Saver also pays just 0.2 per cent.

Savers should seriously consider switching their money to another provider for a better rate.

Family BS pays 1.34 per cent on its Market Tracker Saver available online, by post or through its branch in Epsom, Surrey.

The rate is set at the average of the 20 best rates plus 0.05 percentage points.

It would earn you an extra £131 a year more in interest on each £10,000 compared to if you left it in TSB’s account paying 0.15 per cent.

With Coventry BS Limited Access Isa the rate is a higher 1.46 per cent, but you are limited to making three withdrawals a year.

The rate is also boosted by a 0.31 per cent bonus until January 2021 when the rate drops to 1.15 per cent. It’s available online, by post or in its branches.

To switch your cash Isa, ask your new provider to arrange the transfer for you.
